claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers a local innate sensing and strong type I interferon signaling response within the tumor microenvironment.

evidence.quote: intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination significantly expands the repertoire of tumor-associated peptides presented on MHC-I, effectively increasing tumor visibility to T cells.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models, suggesting the T cell response is insufficient without checkpoint blockade.

claims.claim: Combining intratumoral mRNA vaccination with checkpoint blockade results in a synergistic anti-tumor effect, increasing T-cell infiltration and making the checkpoint axis more targetable.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy
PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors, and ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline settings.

claims.claim: In a retrospective analysis, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination is statistically associated with improved survival outcomes in metastatic cancer patients treated with Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors (ICI).

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

The study supports a biologically coherent hypothesis that intratumoral mRNA vaccination can prime tumors for stronger ICI responses, but prospective randomized studies are required before clinical protocol changes are justified.

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely, and vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
